items.summary: It's fair to say when a Brisbane resident woke up to discover a carpet python curled up on top of her, she was rattled.

items.title: Former Whyalla steelworks owner's $18.5 million royalties debt revealed
items.summary: The former owner of the Whyalla steelworks, Sanjeev Gupta's OneSteel Manufacturing, owed $18.5 million in royalties when it was forced into administration last year, the ABC can reveal.

items.title: Hundreds of satellite images capture Victoria's destructive bushfires erupting
items.summary: Hundreds of images captured by an orbiting weather satellite, and stitched together by the ABC, show the scale and destructive force of the Victorian bushfires.

items.title: What is in the government's new hate speech laws?
items.summary: Parliament will return early next week to debate new hate speech laws. But what exactly does the legislation include?

items.title: Heated Rivalry and growing sports romance genre can teach lessons about queer inclusion
items.summary: Heated Rivalry has become a massive global hit, but can the steamy ice hockey romance, and other queer love stories, help create more inclusive spaces in the real sporting world?

items.title: Australia's notorious Bass Strait was once conquered by two men in a 4.5m dinghy
items.summary: With whisky and lollies for sustenance and pigeons their only means of communication, Steve Harris and Doug Fleming crossed Bass Strait in a 4.5m dinghy in 1974.

items.title: Trump threatens to invoke Insurrection Act over Minnesota anti-ICE protests
items.summary: Such a move would allow the president to deploy troops to quell persistent protests in the city of Minneapolis, where two shootings connected to immigration crackdowns are fuelling public anger.

items.title: Pulp agree to Adelaide Festival show after apology to Randa Abdel-Fattah
items.summary: In a social media post, British indie band Pulp says it had previously informed festival organisers of its decision to withdraw but was asked "to delay an announcement while [organisers] sought to resolve this crisis for all sides", and it had now agreed to perform.

items.title: Antidepressants less effective for many living with atypical depression, new study finds
items.summary: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for about 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.

items.title: More than 4.7m social media accounts closed in two days after ban began, data reveals
items.summary: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

items.title: Space station astronauts splash down after first-ever medical evacuation
items.summary: A capsule carrying four International Space Station crew members has splashed down in the Pacific, bringing their mission to an end more than a month early.

items.title: Ecologist Dr Faith Coleman steps down from government panels after allegations of political interference
items.summary: South Australian ecologist Dr Faith Coleman has resigned from two state government algal bloom panels and criticised the state government's approach.

items.title: Premier Jacinta Allan vows to request formal review into Victoria's bushfire disaster
items.summary: Jacinta Allan vows to request a formal review of the state's disastrous bushfire season, following days of questions over issues like Country Fire Authority resourcing and the state's disaster preparedness.

items.title: Wikipedia is 25, but some old fights are still going
items.summary: Wikipedia is celebrating 25 years of the online encyclopedia and the enormous impact its had, while looking forward to its future. But some controversies from the past refuse to die.

items.title: Thursday finance with David Chau
items.summary: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

items.title: Bushfire relief payments cause confusion among Victorians in impact zones
items.summary: Residents from Victoria's bushfire-affected areas say they are confused over disaster relief payments, with a number of people saying they have been rejected for relief despite experiencing hardship.

items.title: Negin Ghadimi wanted to share her voice in protest with Iranians. She died in her father's arms
items.summary: Negin Ghadimi, a 28-year-old bio-electrical engineer who wanted to be "the voice" of Iranians, was shot in the stomach and killed in anti-government protests last week, her bereaved uncle says.

items.title: Survivors of Rottnest seaplane crash recall moments after impact, thanking those who saved them
items.summary: Jeremy and Patricia Connor have publicly thanked those who rushed to help after the one-year anniversary of the crash.

items.title: Driver's licence suspended after dog dies in alleged hit and run
items.summary: A man's licence is suspended as police investigate the death of a dog in an alleged hit and run near Newcastle.

items.title: International Grammar School teacher Peter Adam in custody over child sexual abuse claims
items.summary: A Sydney school teacher accused of plotting the sexual assault of two children he was allegedly "pimping out" to another man is refused bail.

items.title: Three-year-old Ineza King dies following Banya truck crash
items.summary: A three-year-old girl who suffered critical head injuries in a horrific multi-vehicle crash last week in regional Queensland has died in hospital, with her family remembering her as a "beautiful spirit".

items.title: United Employment collapse leaves disability workers $6 million short in missing pay, super and entitlements
items.summary: Up to 500 workers are fighting to recoup pay, super and entitlements after the collapse of a large disability support provider operating in New South Wales.

items.title: Laura Stein appointed as South Australia's new Chief Justice, replacing Chris Kourakis
items.summary: Supreme Court Justice Laura Stein has been announced as South Australia's new Chief Justice — the first woman to be appointed to the role.

items.title: Police investigating fraud claim against director of liquidated caravan manufacturer Zone RV
items.summary: The luxury caravan manufacturer will be wound up, with liquidators promising to step up their investigation into allegations against Zone RV director David Biggar.

items.title: Name change for viral app Are You Dead, designed for young people living alone
items.summary: A viral Chinese app named Are You Dead aimed at people living alone has been rebranded to avoid controversy.

items.title: Thanasi Kokkinakis pulls out of Australian Open singles, hopeful Special Ks can still play doubles
items.summary: Thanasi Kokkinakis has pulled out of the Australian Open singles before the draw could be announced after suffering a shoulder injury playing in Adelaide.

items.title: Behind Grok's mass digital undressing lies an 'unsurprising' cohort of 'men eager to violate women'
items.summary: The X AI is not creating sexually explicit images of women on its own, but the software "facilitates their abuse" acting on the requests of men "eager to violate women".

items.title: Anxious business owners fear collateral damage from WA's illegal tobacco violence
items.summary: Business owners neighbouring suspected illegal tobacco stores are calling for a crackdown amid a spate of violent incidents alleged to be targeting the illicit tobacco trade.

items.title: Dane Sweeny battles into Australian Open main draw
items.summary: A delighted Dane Sweeny will play in the Australian Open main draw for the second time after winning his third and final qualifying match.

items.title: Federal officer shoots man in leg in Minneapolis after being attacked during arrest, officials say
items.summary: A federal law enforcement officer has shot a man in the leg in Minneapolis after being attacked with a shovel and broom handle during an arrest, US officials say.

items.title: Surgeons appear in court over alleged secret payments in Queensland hospitals
items.summary: Two surgeons and the co-owner of a medical device company face Brisbane Magistrates court over their alleged involvement in public hospital fraud, allegedly involving secret payments to surgeons.

items.title: Greens won't support Labor's sweeping hate law reform in current form
items.summary: The Greens have thrown up a roadblock for Labor by declaring it will not support the government's sweeping changes to hate and gun laws without amendments as the Coalition also backs away from the reforms.

items.title: Iran internet blackout enters seventh day as US President Donald Trump says violence has 'stopped'
items.summary: Washington could intervene militarily in Iran, the Trump administration has suggested, but it remains unclear whether that will happen.

items.title: Why Australia is investing in defence infrastructure at five military sites in the Philippines
items.summary: Experts say these agreements are clear signs of how important an ally the Philippines is becoming in the Indo-Pacific region amid jitters of US security guarantees.

items.title: WA health infrastructure audit delivers scathing assessment of hospital maintenance
items.summary: An audit of WA's health infrastructure finds the state's aging public hospitals are too reliant on reactive maintenance, with no dedicated funding to keep them up to scratch and little data to inform future decisions.

items.title: Blooming corpse flower at Adelaide Botanic Garden set to attract thousands
items.summary: A corpse flower at the Adelaide Botanic Garden is generating excitement but it is actually among five of the rare plant to bloom in the city this summer.

items.title: Tom Silvagni, son of AFL star, outlines rape conviction appeal grounds
items.summary: Details of the 23-year-old's appeal bid have been released, with Silvagni arguing a judge erred in describing certain evidence as "incriminating conduct" during his rape trial late last year.

items.title: Neo-Nazi figure Joel Davis denied bail over alleged threat to federal MP
items.summary: High-ranking neo-Nazi Joel Davis has told a Sydney court the Nationalist Socialist Network "no longer exists" as he was again denied bail for allegedly threatening a federal MP.

items.title: Antonio Arena scores for Roma, raising questions over whether he will play for the Socceroos or Italy
items.summary: In Italy, he has earned the nickname Il Baby Bomber because of his size, strength and impact on the game. But where do his international allegiances lie?

items.title: Australian Open 2026 draw puts Alex de Minaur against former Wimbledon finalist in tough first round
items.summary: In the first round, the world number six will face off against Matteo Berrettini, a former Australian Open semifinalist — a place De Minaur has never progressed to himself.

items.title: From dumped shark heads to rising fury — how WA's demersal fishing ban turned ugly
items.summary: Western Australia's ban on demersal fishing has left fishers frustrated. Will the government be able to soften the blow for an angry industry?

items.summary: Jordan Smith comes from a tennis-mad family in Sydney and is now a millionaire thanks to a couple of days' work at the Australian Open.

items.title: Families displaced by Victorian bushfires face uncertain future in tight rental market
items.summary: Four weeks after unpacking their last box, a Harcourt family fled fire with only their passports and clothes — and now face a difficult search for a new rental.

items.title: Australian Open 2026: Record crowds for 'Opening Week' leave some fans frustrated
items.summary: The Australian Open has smashed attendance records in what is being marketed as "Opening Week", featuring fan events and qualifying matches, but the main draw does not start until Sunday.

items.title: Workers on Melbourne farm supplying Woolworths, Coles chase unpaid wages worth $260,000
items.summary: According to court documents, at least 20 workers are owed money for the work they did in late 2023 on Corrigan's Farm in south-east Melbourne, which experts say is part of a bigger problem that sees tens of millions in missing cash disappear into the black economy.

items.title: Stolen Generation artwork discovered in trunk of regional WA museum
items.summary: An artwork drawn by a child of the Stolen Generations more than 70 years ago is discovered after decades in the trunk of a regional museum.

items.title: River Murray, Coorong, Lake Alexandrina listed as critically endangered
items.summary: Environmental protections along a huge stretch of the River Murray will be boosted, following a decision to officially list the area as "critically endangered", the federal government says.

items.title: Adelaide Festival Corporation apologises to Randa Abdel-Fattah over Adelaide Writers' Week call
items.summary: The Adelaide Festival Corporation, which oversees Adelaide Writers' Week, has apologised to Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah and says she will be invited to speak at its next event in 2027.

items.title: Two French men to plead guilty over alleged $10m luxury theft in Canberra
items.summary: Lawyers say the value of the allegedly stolen luxury goods, including a $5 million Richard Mille watch, is disputed as the case returns to court.

items.title: SpaceX capsule begins return to Earth from International Space Station with sick astronaut on board
items.summary: The Crew Dragon capsule has undocked from the International Space Station carrying four astronauts, one of whom has a "serious medical condition", and is on its way back to Earth.

items.title: Calls for greater transparency as WA government's annual reports into youth suicide delayed
items.summary: Fearing more lives will be lost, Kimberley Aboriginal leaders call on the WA government to release updates on parliamentary and coronial recommendations into youth suicide.

items.title: Why Alice Springs has become one of Australia's most prolific literary towns
items.summary: With many local authors, Alice Springs is no longer just a setting for stories by writers from elsewhere. It is becoming one of Australia's most distinctive literary centres with homegrown talent inspired by the Red Centre's landscape.

items.title: Coalition asks Albanese for the grace he was not afforded in the wake of Bondi attack
items.summary: Federal Liberals are discovering the price of having been so brazen in their politicisation of the Bondi terror attack and many appear to have buyers' remorse.

items.title: Police say 11 explosive devices found on Canberra streets
items.summary: Eleven explosive devices have been found next to footpaths in the city's north-west in the past two days, ACT police say.

items.title: Drought-hit grain growers make every drop of rain count
items.summary: New techniques and technology are allowing southern NSW grain growers to produce a harvest, despite significantly below-average rainfall.

items.title: Brisbane Heat beat Hobart Hurricanes in stunning BBL finish
items.summary: A spectacular bowling effort in the final overs and a key contribution from Marnus Labuschagne help the Brisbane Heat to an upset win over the Hobart Hurricanes to keep their BBL finals hopes alive.

items.title: Australia's vet access deserts where an hour's drive is the difference in life and death
items.summary: More than 250,000 people do not have ready access to a vet in Australia, and according to the industry, it is not completely down to a shortage. It is also a distribution issue, which is putting biosecurity at risk.

items.title: Regulator investigates alleged breach of Alcoa's mining exemption conditions
items.summary: WA's environmental regulator is investigating an alleged breach of Alcoa's state-imposed mining conditions which, if proven, would make it illegal for the company to continue some of its mining operations.

items.title: As Adelaide Writers' Week is cancelled, what is the future of writers' festivals in Australia?
items.summary: The shock cancellation of Adelaide Writers' Week has left many concerned about the future of writers' festivals in an increasingly polarised political world.

items.title: Volunteer firefighters, councils paying for Starlink connections as poor mobile reception continues across WA
items.summary: Having repeatedly lost mobile coverage during recent bushfires, local councils and volunteer brigades are paying for expensive satellite units to maintain critical communications.
